Throughout the 1970s when the price of aviation fuel started spiraling upward, NASA aeronautical engineer [[Richard Whitcomb]] began investigating and studying the feasibility of winglets in order to improve overall aerodynamics and reduce drag on aircraft. Whitcomb's tests finally culminated with the first successful test flight of his attached winglets on a [[KC-135 Stratotanker]] on July 24, 1979.<ref>{{cite web|title=Winglets|publisher=NASA|url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/dryden/about/Organizations/Technology/Facts/TF-2004-15-DFRC.html }}</ref>
'''1979 [[Polar fleece]]'''
Polar fleece, or "fleece", is a soft napped insulating synthetic wool fabric made from polyethylene terephthalate or other synthetic fibers. Found in jackets, hoodies, and casual wear, fleece has some of wool's finest qualities but weighs a fraction of the lightest available woolens. The first form of polar fleece was invented in 1979 by [[Malden Mills]], now Polartec LLC., which was a new, light, and strong pile fabric meant to mimic and in some ways surpass wool.<ref>{{cite web|title=Polar Fleece|publisher=Stitch n Save|url=http://www.stitchnsave.com/fleece/Polar_Fleece.asp}}</ref>
===1980s and the early 1990s (1980–1991)=== [[File:F-117 Nighthawk Front.jpg|180px|left|thumb| F-117 Nighthawk flying over mountains in Nevada in 2002]] '''1981 [[Stealth-aircraft]]''' * The [[Lockheed F-117 Nighthawk]] was the world's first operational aircraft to be designed around [[stealth technology]]. Its maiden flight took place in 1981, and the aircraft achieved [[initial operating capability]] status in 1983.
'''1981 [[Control-Alt-Delete]]''' * Control-Alt-Delete, often abbreviated as Ctrl-Alt-Del, is a computer keyboard command on PC compatible systems that can be used to reboot a computer, and summon the task manager or operating system. It is invoked by pressing the Delete key while holding the Control and Alt keys: Ctrl+Alt+Delete. Thus, it forces a soft reboot, brings up the task manager (on Windows and BeOS) or a jump to ROM monitor. Control-Alt-Delete was invented in 1981 by [[David Bradley (engineer)|David Bradley]] while working at IBM.<ref>{{cite web|title=Control-Alt-Delete|publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology|url=http://web.mit.edu/invent/iow/bradley.html}}</ref>
'''1981 [[Total internal reflection fluorescence microscope]]''' * A total internal reflection fluorescence microscope is a type of microscope with which a thin region of a specimen, usually less than 200 nm, can be observed. It can also be used to observe the fluorescence of a single molecule, making it an important tool of biophysics and quantitative biology. Daniel Axelrod invented the first total internal reflection fluorescence microscope in 1981.<ref>{{cite web|title=Total Internal Reflection Fluorescence for Single Molecule Studies|publisher=University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|url=http://online.physics.uiuc.edu/courses/phys552/fall08/Reports/2008/EJ%20PHY%20552%20Final%20Paper.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326092310/http://online.physics.uiuc.edu/courses/phys552/fall08/Reports/2008/EJ%20PHY%20552%20Final%20Paper.pdf|archivedate=March 26, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
'''1981 [[Space shuttle]]''' [[File:STS-79 rollout.jpg|180px|left|thumb|The Space Shuttle: World's most complex machine]] The Space Shuttle, part of the Space Transportation System (STS), is a spacecraft operated by NASA for orbital human spaceflight missions. It carries payloads to low Earth orbit, provides crew rotation for the International Space Station (ISS), and performs servicing missions. The orbiter can also recover satellites and other payloads from orbit and return them to Earth. In 1981, NASA successfully launched its reusable spacecraft called the Space Shuttle. [[George Mueller (NASA)|George Mueller]], an American from St. Louis, Missouri is widely credited for jump starting, designing, and overseeing the Space Shuttle program after the demise of the Apollo program in 1972.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Space Shuttle's First Flight: STS-1|publisher=NASA|url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4219/Chapter12.html}}</ref>
'''1981 [[Paintball]]'''
Paintball is a game in which players eliminate opponents by hitting them with pellets containing paint usually shot from a carbon dioxide or compressed-gas, HPA or N20, in a powered paintball gun. The idea of the game was first conceived and co-invented in 1976 by Hayes Noel, Bob Gurnsey, and Charles Gaines. However, the game of paintball was not first played until June 27, 1981.<ref>{{cite web|title=Splat attack|publisher=BBC|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/leicester/fun_stuff/2004/01/leicester_wildcast_report.shtml}}</ref>
'''1981 [[Graphic User Interface]]'''
Short for Graphic User Interface, the GUI uses windows, icons, and menus to carry out commands such as opening files, deleting files, moving files, etc. and although many GUI Operating Systems are operated by using a mouse, the keyboard can also be used by using keyboard shortcuts or arrow keys. The GUI was co-invented at Xerox PARC by [[Alan Kay]] and [[Douglas Engelbart]] in 1981.<ref>{{cite web|title=A History of the GUI|publisher=Condé Nast Digital, Inc|url=https://arstechnica.com/old/content/2005/05/gui.ars}}</ref>
'''1983 [[Internet]]''' [[File:Arpanet logical map, march 1977.png|180px|left|thumb|ARPANET logical map, 1977]] Not to be confused with a separate application known as the [[World wide web]] which was invented much later in the early 1990s (see article on the English inventor [[Tim Berners-Lee]]), the Internet is the global system of overall interconnected computer networks that use the standardized [[Internet Protocol Suite]] (TCP/IP) to serve billions of users worldwide. It is a network of networks that consists of millions of private and public, academic, business, and government networks of local to global scope that are linked by copper wires, fiber-optic cables, wireless connections, and other technologies. The concept of [[packet switching]] of a network was first explored by [[Paul Baran]] in the early 1960s,<ref>{{cite web|title=Paul Baran Invents Packet Switching|publisher=Living Internet|url=http://www.livinginternet.com/i/ii_rand.htm}}</ref> and the mathematical formulations behind packet switching were later devised by [[Leonard Kleinrock]].<ref>{{cite web|title=UCLA's Leonard Kleinrock to receive National Medal of Science|publisher=University of California|url=http://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/news/article/18437|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204193515/http://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/news/article/18437|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2008-12-04}}</ref> On October 29, 1969, the world's first electronic computer network, the [[ARPANET]], was established between nodes at Leonard Kleinrock's lab at UCLA and [[Douglas Engelbart]]'s lab at the Stanford Research Institute (now [[SRI International]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sri.com/work/timeline-innovation/timeline.php?timeline=computing-digital#&innovation=arpanet|title=ARPANET|work=Timeline of Innovations|publisher=[[SRI International]]|accessdate=2013-07-01}}</ref> Another milestone occurred in 1973 when [[Bob Kahn]] and [[Vinton Cerf]] co-invented [[Internet Protocol]] and [[Transmission Control Protocol]] while working on ARPANET at the [[United States Department of Defense]].<ref name="The Great Idea Finder"/> The first TCP/IP-wide area network was operational on January 1, 1983, when the United States' [[National Science Foundation]] (NSF) constructed the university network backbone that would later become the NSFNet. This date is held as the "birth" of the Internet.<ref>{{cite web|title=Computing History, 1981–1985: The Internet|publisher=Computing Networking Services|url=http://docweb.cns.ufl.edu/update/u030604a/u030604a.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=A Brief History of the Internet|publisher=University System of Georgia|url=http://www.usg.edu/galileo/skills/unit07/internet07_02.phtml}}</ref>
'''1983 [[Blind signature]]''' * In cryptography, a blind signature, as invented by [[David Chaum]] in 1983, is a form of digital signature in which the content of a message is disguised before it is signed. The resulting blind signature can be publicly verified against the original, unblinded message in the manner of a regular digital signature. Blind signatures are typically employed in privacy-related protocols where the signer and message author are different parties. Examples include cryptographic election systems and digital cash schemes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Digital Cash|publisher=University of Birmingham|url=http://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/~gzw/teaching/netsec08/Lectures/Digital%20Cash.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815211323/http://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/~gzw/teaching/netsec08/Lectures/Digital%20Cash.pdf|archivedate=August 15, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
'''1983 [[Laser turntable]]''' * A laser turntable is a phonograph that plays gramophone records using a laser beam as the pickup instead of a conventional diamond-tipped stylus. This playback system has the unique advantage of avoiding physical contact with the record during playback; instead, a focused beam of light traces the signal undulations in the vinyl, with zero friction, mass and record wear. The laser turntable was first conceived by Robert S. Reis, while working as a consultant of analog signal processing for the United States Air Force and the United States Department of Defense.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Lasers Gove New Life to Old LP's|publisher=Reed Business Information|date=1988-02-18|url=https://books.google.com/?id=U-E41USJb5oC&pg=PA40&lpg=PA40&dq=Robert+S.+Reis+laser+turn+table#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
'''1984 [[LCD projector]]''' * An LCD projector is a type of [[video projector]] for displaying video, images or computer data on a screen or other flat surface. It is a modern equivalent of the [[slide projector]] or [[overhead projector]]. To display images, LCD ([[liquid-crystal display]]) projectors typically send light from a metal-halide lamp through a prism or series of dichroic filters that separates light to three polysilicon panels – one each for the red, green and blue components of the video signal. The LCD projector was invented in 1984 by [[Gene Dolgoff]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Milestones|publisher=InfoComm International|url=http://www.infocomm.org/cps/rde/xchg/infocomm/hs.xsl/10664.htm}}</ref>
'''1984 [[Pointing stick]]''' * The pointing stick is an isometric joystick operated by applied force and is used as a pointing device on laptop computers. It takes the form of a rubber cap located on top of the keyboard embedded between the 'G', 'H' and 'B' keys. The pointing stick was invented by American computer scientist [[Ted Selker]] in 1984.<ref>{{cite book|title=Pressure Sensitive User Interface WithAffective Measurement|publisher=New York University|url=http://cs.nyu.edu/~lixin/index_files/xin.pdf}}</ref>
'''1984 [[Polymerase chain reaction]]''' * The polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is a technique widely used in molecular biology. It derives its name from one of its key components, a DNA polymerase used to amplify a piece of DNA by ''in vitro'' enzymatic DNA replication. As PCR progresses, the DNA generated is used as a template for replication. The polymerase chain reaction was invented in 1984 by [[Kary Mullis]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Kary Mullis – biography|publisher=KaryMullis.com|url=http://www.karymullis.com/bio.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119211724/http://www.karymullis.com/bio.html|archivedate=January 19, 2008}}</ref>
'''1986 [[Atomic force microscope]]''' * An atomic force microscope is a type of [[microscope]] that is used for imaging, measuring, and manipulating matter at the [[nanoscale]]. The information is gathered by "feeling" the surface with a mechanical probe. Piezoelectric elements that facilitate tiny but accurate and precise movements on (electronic) command enable the very precise scanning. The atomic force microscope was co-invented in 1986 by [[Christoph Gerber]], [[Gerd Binning]], and [[Calvin Quate]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Methods in Modern Biophysics|publisher=Springer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aoYAGLSTgGwC&pg=PA122&dq=Atomic+force+microscope+and+Christoph+Gerber+and+Calvin+Quate&hl=en&ei=jL1ATsX0BoOFtgeezo2yCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> On April 20, 1987, Gerber, Binning, and Quate filed U.S. patent #4,762,996 for the device which was later issued to them on August 9, 1988.<ref>{{cite web|title=Coarse approach positioning device|publisher=United States Patent and Trademark Office|url=http://www.google.com/patents?id=xms0AAAAEBAJ&printsec=abstract&zoom=4#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
'''1986 [[Stereolithography]]''' * Stereolithography is a common rapid manufacturing and rapid prototyping technology for producing parts with high accuracy and good surface finish by utilizing a vat of liquid UV-curable photopolymer "resin" and a UV laser to build parts a layer at a time. Stereolithography was invented by [[Chuck Hull]] in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|title=Introduction to StereoLithography Apparatus (SLA) |publisher=Rapid Product Development Resource Centre |url=http://rpdrc.ic.polyu.edu.hk/content/rp_for_arch_short_guide_3.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081004062001/http://rpdrc.ic.polyu.edu.hk/content/rp_for_arch_short_guide_3.htm |archivedate=October 4, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
'''1987 [[Digital Micromirror Device]]''' * The Digital Micromirror Device (DMD) is a silicon chip of up to 2 million hinged microscopic aluminum mirrors all under digital control that tilt thousands of times per second in order to create an image by directing digital pulses through a projection lens and onto a television or movie theatre screen. The Digital Micromirror Device was invented by Dr. Larry Hornbeck while working at Texas Instruments, also holding several patents relating to DMD technology.<ref>{{cite web|title=Digital micromirror device – DMD |publisher=National Inventors Hall of Fame |url=http://www.invent.org/2009induction/1_3_09_induction_hornbeck.asp |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110108121936/http://www.invent.org/2009induction/1_3_09_induction_hornbeck.asp |archivedate=January 8, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
'''1987 [[Perl]]''' * Perl is a high-level, general-purpose, interpreted, dynamic programming language. It was originally invented by [[Larry Wall]], a linguist working as a systems administrator for NASA, in 1987, as a general purpose Unix scripting language to make report processing easier. Perl is also used for text processing, system administration, web application development, bioinformatics, network programming, applications that require database access, graphics programming etc.<ref>{{cite web|title=Beginner's Introduction to Perl(part 1)|publisher=Perl.com|url=http://www.perl.com/pub/a/2000/10/begperl1.html}}</ref>
'''1988 [[Luggage|Luggage (tilt-and-roll)]]''' [[File:Fluggastbrücke.jpg|180px|left|thumb|Airline passengers rolling their luggage in an airport terminal]] Tilt-and-roll luggage or wheeled luggage, is a variant of luggage for travelers which typically contains two-fixed wheels on one end and a telescoping handle on the opposite end for vertical movement. Tilt-and-roll luggage is pulled and thus eliminates a traveler from directly carrying his or her luggage. In 1988, Northwest Airlines pilot Robert Plath invented tilt-and-roll luggage as travelers beforehand had to carry suitcases in their hands, toss garment bags over their shoulders, or strap luggage on top of metal carts.<ref>{{cite news|title=Success stunned pilot inventor|publisher=USA Today|url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/biztravel/2003-02-19-bagside_x.htm|date=February 19, 2003|first1=Bruce|last1=Horovitz}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Taking the 'lug' out of luggage changed everything|publisher=USA Today|url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/biztravel/2003-02-18-bags_x.htm| date=February 18, 2003|first1=Bruce|last1=Horovitz}}</ref>
'''1988 [[Fused deposition modeling]]''' Fused deposition modeling, which is often referred to by its initials FDM, is a type of additive fabrication or technology commonly used within engineering design. FDM works on an "additive" principle by laying down material in layers. Fusion deposition modeling was invented by [[S. Scott Crump]] in 1988.<ref>{{cite web|title=Highlights of Fused Deposition Modeling|publisher=Engineering Fundamentals|url=http://www.efunda.com/processes/rapid_prototyping/fdm.cfm}}</ref>
'''1988 [[Tcl]]''' Tcl, known as "Tool Command Language", is a scripting language most commonly used for rapid prototyping, scripted applications, GUIs and testing. Tcl is used extensively on embedded systems platforms, both in its full form and in several other small-footprinted versions. Tcl is also used for CGI scripting. Tcl was invented in the spring of 1988 by [[John Ousterhout]] while working at the University of California, Berkeley.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of Tcl|publisher=John Ousterhout|url=http://home.pacbell.net/ouster/tclHistory.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706044612/http://home.pacbell.net/ouster/tclHistory.html|archivedate=July 6, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
'''1988 [[Ballistic electron emission microscopy]]''' Ballistic electron emission microscopy or BEEM is a technique for studying ballistic electron transport through variety of materials and material interfaces. BEEM is a three terminal scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) technique that was co-invented in 1988 at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena California by L. Douglas Bell and William Kaiser.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ballistic-electron-emission microscopy: A nanometer-scale probe of interfaces and carrier transport|publisher=University of Pennsylvania|url=http://garfield.library.upenn.edu/histcomp/annualreviews/ann-rev-mat-sci/node/379.html}}</ref>
'''1988 [[Electron beam ion trap]]''' * The electron beam ion trap is used in physics to denote an electromagnetic bottle that produces and confines highly charged ions. The electron beam ion trap was co-invented by M. Levine and R. Marrs in 1988.<ref>{{cite web|title= EBIT – The Electron Beam Ion Trap|publisher=Livermore Berkeley National Laboratory|url=http://www-ebit.lbl.gov/}}</ref>
'''1988 [[Nicotine patch]]''' * A nicotine patch is a transdermal patch that releases nicotine into the body through the skin. It is usually used as a method to quit smoking. The nicotine patch was invented in 1988 by [[Murray Jarvik]], Jed Rose and Daniel Rose.<ref>{{cite news|title=Murray Jarvik, 84, Whose Research Helped Lead to Nicotine Patch, Dies|publisher=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/13/health/13jarvik.html?_r=1&ref=us | first=Bruce | last=Weber | date=May 13, 2008 | accessdate=May 25, 2010}}</ref>
'''1988 [[Firewall (computing)|Firewall]]''' * A firewall is an integrated collection of security measures designed to prevent unauthorized electronic access to a networked computer system. At [[AT&T]] [[Bell Labs]], [[William Cheswick]] and [[Steven M. Bellovin]] were continuing their research in packet filtering and co-invented a working model for their own company based upon their original first generation architecture of a firewall.<ref>{{cite web|title=One Size Does Not Fit All: Tailoring Protection with Data Proximate Security|publisher=Techworld|url=http://www.techworld.com/whitepapers/index.cfm?whitepaperid=5270}}</ref>
'''1988 [[Resin identification code]]''' * The SPI resin identification coding system is a set of symbols placed on plastics to identify the polymer type. The resin identification code was developed by the Society of the Plastics Industry (SPI) in 1988.<ref>{{cite web|title=SPI Resin Identification Code – Guide to Correct Use|publisher=Society of the Plastics Industry|url=http://www.plasticsindustry.org/AboutPlastics/content.cfm?ItemNumber=823|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516032146/http://www.plasticsindustry.org/AboutPlastics/content.cfm?ItemNumber=823|archivedate=May 16, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
'''1989 [[ZIP (file format)|ZIP file format]]''' * The ZIP file format is a data compression and file archiver. A ZIP file contains one or more files that have been compressed to reduce file size, or stored as-is. The zip file format was originally invented in 1989 by [[Phil Katz]] for PKZIP, and evolved from the previous ARC compression format by Thom Henderson.<ref>{{cite web|title=Philip K. Katz|publisher=Biographies Pioneers of computing A-J|url=http://www.thocp.net/biographies/katz_philip.html}}</ref>
'''1989 [[Selective laser sintering]]''' * Selective laser sintering is an additive rapid manufacturing technique that uses a high power laser to fuse small particles of plastic, metal, ceramic, or glass powders into a mass representing a desired 3-dimensional object. The laser selectively fuses powdered material by scanning cross-sections generated from a 3-D digital description of the part on the surface of a powder bed. Selective laser sintering was invented and patented by Dr. Carl Deckard at the University of Texas at Austin in 1989.<ref>{{cite web|title=US Patent 5053090 – Selective laser sintering with assisted powder handling|publisher=Patent Storm|url=http://www.patentstorm.us/patents/5053090.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813182209/http://www.patentstorm.us/patents/5053090.html|archivedate=August 13, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
'''1990 [[Self-wringing mop]]''' * The self-wringing mop is a type of [[mop]] designed to be wrung out without getting a user's hands wet. The first self-wringing mop was invented in 1990 by [[Joy Mangano]]. The mop head was created from 300 feet of cotton and was developed so that it was possible to be wrung out by turning a plastic handle above the mop head itself. It became widely used in America by the mid 1990s.<ref name="Bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/joy-mangano|accessdate=December 28, 2015|work=Biography|publisher=[[FYI (U.S. TV channel)|FYI]]|title=Joy Mangano}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Joy Mangano|publisher=Oliver Willis|url=http://oliverwillis.com/2015/12/19/joy-mangano-miracle-mop-inventor-facts-photos/}}</ref>
'''1990 [[Sulfur lamp]]''' * The sulfur lamp is a highly efficient full-spectrumelectrodeless lighting system whose light is generated by sulfur plasma that has been excited by microwave radiation. The sulfur lamp consists of a golf ball-sized (30 mm) fused-quartz bulb containing several milligrams of sulfur powder and argon gas at the end of a thin glass spindle. The bulb is enclosed in a microwave-resonant wire-mesh cage. The technology was conceived by engineer Michael Ury, physicist Charles Wood and their colleagues in 1990. With support from the United States Department of Energy, it was further developed in 1994 by Fusion Lighting of Rockville, Maryland, a spinoff of the Fusion UV division of Fusion Systems Corporation.<ref>{{cite web|title=20th Century Inventors: Sulfur Lamp|publisher=Smithsonian Institution|url=http://www.americanhistory.si.edu/lighting/bios/ury.htm}}</ref>
'''1991 [[Ant robotics]]''' * Ant robotics is a special case of [[swarm robotics]]. Swarm robots are simple and cheap robots with limited sensing and computational capabilities. This makes it feasible to deploy teams of swarm robots and take advantage of the resulting fault tolerance and parallelism. In 1991, American electrical engineer [[James McLurkin]] was the first to conceptualize the idea of "robot ants" while working at the [[MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory]] at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]. The robots consisted of sensors, infrared emitters, and communication systems capable of detecting objects in their path. McLurkin's invention was through studying the behavior of real ants in [[Ant colony|ant colonies]] and keeping [[Formicarium|ant farms]] as a basis for his programming. Through this examination, he could better understand how insects structured their workloads in order to produce a viable and working prototype of robotic ants.<ref>{{cite web|title=James McLurkin|publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology|url=http://web.mit.edu/invent/iow/mclurkin.html}}</ref>

[[File:Treadmillcrane.jpg|thumb|A 13th century drawing of a treadwheel crane]] A '''treadwheel crane''' (Latin ''magna rota'') is a wooden, [[animal engine|human powered]], [[Crane (machine)|hoisting and lowering device]]. It was primarily used during the [[Roman Empire|Roman]] period and the [[Middle Ages]] in the building of castles and cathedrals. The often heavy charge is lifted as the individual inside the [[treadwheel]] crane walks. The rope attached to a [[pulley]] is turned onto a [[Spindle (textiles)|spindle]] by the rotation of the wheel thus allowing the device to hoist or lower the affixed pallet.
== History ==
=== Ancient Rome === [[File:KranIBN.JPG|thumb|Reconstruction of a Roman treadwheel crane, the ''Polyspaston'', at [[Bonn]], Germany]] The Roman ''Polyspaston'' crane, when worked by four men at both sides of the [[winch]], could lift 3000 kg. In case the winch was replaced by a treadwheel, the maximum load even doubled to 6000 kg at only half the crew, since the treadwheel possesses a much bigger mechanical advantage due to its larger diameter. This meant that, in comparison to the construction of the ancient [[Egyptian pyramids]], where about 50 men were needed to move a 2.5 ton stone block up the ramp (50 kg per person), the lifting capability of the Roman ''Polyspaston'' proved to be ''60 times'' more efficient (3000 kg per person).<ref>{{harvnb|Dienel|Meighörner|1997|p=13}}</ref> There are two surviving reliefs of Roman treadwheel cranes, the [[Quintus Haterius|Haterii]] tombstone from the late first century AD being particularly detailed.
For larger weights of up to 100 t, Roman engineers set up a wooden lifting tower, a rectangular trestle which was so constructed that the column could be lifted upright in the middle of the structure by the means of human and animal-powered [[Capstan (nautical)|capstans]] placed on the ground around the tower.<ref>{{harvnb|Lancaster|1999|pp=426−432}}</ref>
=== Middle Ages === [[File:Tretkran (Bruegel).jpg|thumb|Pieter Bruegel's construction of ''[[The Tower of Babel (Bruegel)]]'' featuring a double treadwheel crane]]
During the [[High Middle Ages]], the treadwheel crane was reintroduced on a large scale after the technology had fallen into disuse in western Europe with the demise of the [[Western Roman Empire]].<ref>{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|p=514}}</ref> The earliest reference to a treadwheel (''magna rota'') reappears in archival literature in France about 1225,<ref name="Andrea Matthies, p.515">{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|p=515}}</ref> followed by an illuminated depiction in a manuscript of probably also French origin dating to 1240.<ref>{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|p=526}}</ref> In navigation, the earliest uses of harbor cranes are documented for [[Utrecht (city)|Utrecht]] in 1244, [[Antwerp]] in 1263, [[Brugge]] in 1288 and [[Hamburg]] in 1291,<ref name="Matheus 1996, 345">{{harvnb|Matheus|1996|p=345}}</ref> while in England the treadwheel is not recorded before 1331.<ref name="Matthies 1992, 524">{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|p=524}}</ref>
Generally, vertical transport could be done more safely and inexpensively by cranes than by customary methods. Typical areas of application were harbours, mines, and, in particular, building sites where the treadwheel crane played a pivotal role in the construction of the lofty [[Gothic architecture|Gothic cathedrals]]. Nevertheless, both archival and pictorial sources of the time suggest that newly introduced machines like treadwheels or [[wheelbarrow]]s did not completely replace more labor-intensive methods like [[ladder]]s, [[Brick hod|hods]] and handbarrows. Rather, old and new machinery continued to coexist on medieval construction sites<ref>{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|p=545}}</ref> and harbours.<ref name="Matheus 1996, 345"/>
Apart from treadwheels, medieval depictions also show cranes to be powered manually by windlasses with radiating [[spoke]]s, [[Crank (mechanism)|cranks]] and by the 15th century also by windlasses shaped like a [[ship's wheel]]. To smooth out irregularities of impulse and get over 'dead-spots' in the lifting process [[flywheel]]s are known to be in use as early as 1123.<ref>{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|p=518}}</ref>
The exact process by which the treadwheel crane was reintroduced is not recorded,<ref name="Andrea Matthies, p.515"/> although its return to construction sites has undoubtedly to be viewed in close connection with the simultaneous rise of Gothic architecture. The reappearance of the treadwheel crane may have resulted from a technological development of the [[windlass]] from which the treadwheel structurally and mechanically evolved. Alternatively, the medieval treadwheel may represent a deliberate reinvention of its Roman counterpart drawn from [[Vitruvius]]' ''[[De architectura]]'' which was available in many monastic libraries. Its reintroduction may have been inspired, as well, by the observation of the labor-saving qualities of the [[Water wheel|waterwheel]] with which early treadwheels shared many structural similarities.<ref name="Matthies 1992, 524"/>
==== Structure and placement ==== [[File:Reconstruction of the temple of Jerusalem.jpg|thumb|Single treadwheel crane working from top of the building]]
The medieval treadwheel was a large wooden wheel turning around a [[Axle|central shaft]] with a treadway wide enough for two workers walking side by side. While the earlier 'compass-arm' wheel had spokes directly driven into the central shaft, the more advanced 'clasp-arm' type featured arms arranged as chords to the wheel rim,<ref>{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|pp=525f.}}</ref> giving the possibility of using a thinner shaft and providing thus a greater mechanical advantage.<ref>{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|p=536}}</ref>
Contrary to a popularly held belief, cranes on medieval building sites were neither placed on the extremely lightweight [[scaffolding]] used at the time nor on the thin walls of the Gothic churches which were incapable of supporting the weight of both hoisting machine and load. Rather, cranes were placed in the initial stages of construction on the ground, often within the building. When a new floor was completed, and massive tie beams of the roof connected the walls, the crane was dismantled and reassembled on the roof beams from where it was moved from bay to bay during construction of the vaults.<ref name="Matthies 1992, 533">{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|p=533}}</ref> Thus, the crane ‘grew’ and ‘wandered’ with the building with the result that today all extant construction cranes in England are found in church towers above the vaulting and below the roof, where they remained after building construction for bringing material for repairs aloft.<ref>{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|pp=532ff.}}</ref>
Less frequently, medieval illuminations also show cranes mounted on the outside of walls with the stand of the machine secured to putlogs.<ref>{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|p=535}}</ref>
==== Mechanics and operation ==== [[File:Medieval crane - Brugge.jpg|thumb|Reconstructed gantry crane of [[Brugge]] operated by two lateral treadwheels]]
In contrast to modern cranes, medieval cranes and hoists - much like their counterparts in Greece and Rome<ref name="Coulton 1974, 6" >{{harvnb|Coulton|1974|p=6}}</ref> - were primarily capable of a vertical lift, and not used to move loads for a considerable distance horizontally as well.<ref name="Matthies 1992, 533"/> Accordingly, lifting work was organized at the workplace in a different way than today. In building construction, for example, it is assumed that the crane lifted the stone blocks either from the bottom directly into place,<ref name="Matthies 1992, 533"/> or from a place opposite the centre of the wall from where it could deliver the blocks for two teams working at each end of the wall.<ref name="Coulton 1974, 6"/> Additionally, the crane master who usually gave orders at the treadwheel workers from outside the crane was able to manipulate the movement laterally by a small rope attached to the load.<ref name="Dienel, Meighörner 1997, 17">{{harvnb|Dienel|Meighörner|1997|p=17}}</ref> Slewing cranes which allowed a rotation of the load and were thus particularly suited for dockside work appeared as early as 1340.<ref>{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|p=534}}</ref> While ashlar blocks were directly lifted by sling, lewis or devil's clamp (German ''Teufelskralle''), other objects were placed before in containers like [[pallet]]s, [[basket]]s, wooden boxes or [[barrel]]s.<ref>{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|p=531}}</ref>
It is noteworthy that medieval cranes rarely featured [[Ratchet (device)|ratchets]] or [[brake]]s to forestall the load from running backward.<ref>{{harvnb|Matthies|1992|p=540}}</ref> This curious absence is explained by the high [[Friction|friction force]] exercised by medieval treadwheels which normally prevented the wheel from accelerating beyond control.<ref name="Dienel, Meighörner 1997, 17"/>
==== Harbour usage ==== [[File:Trier Germany Alter Krahnen.jpg|thumb|left|Tower crane at the inland harbour of [[Trier]] from 1413]]
According to the "present state of knowledge" unknown in antiquity, stationary harbour cranes are considered a new development of the Middle Ages.<ref name="Matheus 1996, 345"/> The typical harbour crane was a pivoting structure equipped with double treadwheels. These cranes were placed docksides for the loading and unloading of cargo where they replaced or complemented older lifting methods like [[see-saw]]s, [[winch]]es and [[Yard (sailing)|yards]].<ref name="Matheus 1996, 345"/>
Two different types of harbour cranes can be identified with a varying geographical distribution: While gantry cranes which pivoted on a central vertical axle were commonly found at the Flemish and Dutch coastside, German sea and inland harbours typically featured tower cranes where the windlass and treadwheels were situated in a solid tower with only jib arm and roof rotating.<ref name="Matheus 1996, 346">{{harvnb|Matheus|1996|p=346}}</ref> Dockside cranes were not adopted in the Mediterranean region and the highly developed Italian ports where authorities continued to rely on the more labor-intensive method of unloading goods by ramps beyond the Middle Ages.<ref>{{harvnb|Matheus|1996|p=347}}</ref>
Unlike construction cranes where the work speed was determined by the relatively slow progress of the masons, harbour cranes usually featured double treadwheels to speed up loading. The two treadwheels whose diameter is estimated to be 4 m or larger were attached to each side of the axle and rotated together.<ref name="Matheus 1996, 345"/> Their capacity was 2–3 tons which apparently corresponded to the customary size of marine cargo.<ref name="Matheus 1996, 345"/> Today, according to one survey, fifteen treadwheel harbour cranes from pre-industrial times are still extant throughout Europe.<ref>These are Bergen, Stockholm, Karlskrona (Sweden), Kopenhagen (Denmark), Harwich (England), Gdańsk (Poland), Lüneburg, Stade, Otterndorf, Marktbreit, Würzburg, Östrich, Bingen, Andernach and Trier (Germany). Cf. {{harvnb|Matheus|1996|p=346}}</ref> Some harbour cranes were specialised at mounting masts to newly built sailing ships, such as in [[Danzig]], [[Cologne]] and [[Bremen]].<ref name="Matheus 1996, 346"/> Beside these stationary cranes, [[crane vessel|floating cranes]] which could be flexibly deployed in the whole port basin came into use by the 14th century.<ref name="Matheus 1996, 346"/>
== Surviving examples == {{Further|List of historical harbour cranes}}
=== Original ===
A treadwheel crane survives at [[Chesterfield]], [[Derbyshire]] and is housed in the Museum. It has been dated to the early 14th century and was housed in the top of the church tower until its removal in 1947. It was reconstructed in the Museum for its opening in 1994.
A treadwheel crane survives at [[Guildford]], [[Surrey]], [[United Kingdom]]. It dates from the late 17th or early 18th century and formerly stood in Friary Street. It was moved in 1970, having last been used ''ca.'' 1960 to move materials for [[Guildford Cathedral]]. It is a [[Scheduled monument|Scheduled Ancient Monument]] and a [[Listed building|Grade II* listed building]].<ref name=Guildford>{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=289006 |title=THE TREADWHEEL CRANE, MILLBROOK (west side), GUILDFORD, GUILDFORD, SURREY |publisher=English Heritage |accessdate=28 October 2009}}</ref>
A treadwheel crane survives at [[Harwich]], [[Essex]], United Kingdom. It was built in 1667 and formerly stood in the Naval Yard. It was moved to Harwich Green in 1932. The crane has two treadwheels of {{convert|16|ft|m|2}} diameter by {{convert|3|ft|10|in|m|2}} wide on an axle {{convert|13+1/2|in|mm}} diameter. It is the only double wheel treadwheel crane in the United Kingdom.<ref name=Harwich>{{cite web|url=http://www.harwich-society.co.uk/old/info_treadwheel.htm|title=Treadwheel Crane |publisher=The Harwich Society |accessdate=28 October 2009}}</ref> The crane is a Grade II* listed building.<ref name=Harwich2>{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=366522 |title=OLD NAVAL YARD CRANE, HARWICH GREEN, HARWICH, TENDRING, ESSEX |publisher=English Heritage |accessdate=28 October 2009}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Guildford treadwheel crane.jpg|Guildford treadwheel crane File:Harwich treadwheel crane.jpg|Harwich treadwheel crane </gallery>
=== Reconstructions ===
A reconstruction of a 13th-century treadwheel crane can be seen in action at the site [[Guédelon Castle]], [[Treigny]], [[France]]. It is used for lifting mortar, rubble, [[ashlar]] blocks, and wood. The object of Guédelon Castle is to build a fortress castle using only the techniques and materials of 13th-century medieval France.
<gallery class="center"> File:squirrelcage.jpg|A treadwheel crane or 'squirrel cage' at Guédelon Castle. </gallery>
[[Gdansk]] Crane<ref>[[:pl:Brama Żuraw w Gdańsku]]</ref> ({{lang-pl |Żuraw}}) ({{lang-de |Krantor}}) was built before 1366. It was destroyed by the soviet troops during the fighting for the city in early 1945. The brick structure survived, the wooden parts have been restored.
<gallery class="center"> File:Pl_gdansk_zuraw_dlugiepobrzeze2006.jpg|Gdansk Crane </gallery>
A reconstruction of a double wheel treadwheel crane is in use at [[Prague]] Castle, [[Czech Republic]].<ref name=Tocnik>{{cite web|url=http://www.radio.cz/en/article/82857 |title=Man-powered medieval crane at Prague Castle |publisher=Radio Praha |accessdate=28 October 2009}}</ref>
A Treadwheel Crane was used in the film ''[[Evan Almighty]]'', when Evan complained to God that he needed a crane to construct the Ark in suburban Washington, D.C.
